Resident Mission  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The technical assistance1 (TA) will respond to a request by the Government of Bhutan 
for support from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to accelerate and consolidate key aspects 
of its governance and development agenda. The TA for Strengthening Public Management is 
included in the Bhutan country operations business plan (2011–2013).2 A consultation mission 
in September 2010 and a fact-finding mission in November 2010 formulated the goals and 
strategies  of  the  TA  and  designed  its  corresponding  activities.  Extensive  discussion  with 
government officials has resulted in mutual agreement on the design and monitoring ramework 
(Appendix 1) and outline terms of references for consultants ( Appendix 3). 
 
2.   The TA supports the government’s priorities outlined in its Tenth Five-Year Plan (2008–
2013),3 which identifies decentralized governance as a crosscutting development strategy. The 
TA also supports the implementation of Bhutan’s recently drafted local government capacity 
development strategy4 and a newly proposed municipal finance policy.5 
 
3.  The TA will build on the work of an ongoing TA project that is delivering leadership and 
management training for government officials,6 and on another TA project on strengthening public 
financial management.7 It will support local government finance reforms and the mainstreaming of 
regulatory impact analysis in policy making. The TA will pioneer innovative activities in local 
government finance, e-governance, social audit, civil service, and regulatory reform. 
 
4.  The  TA  supports  ADB’s  Bhutan  country  partnership  strategy.8 By  improving  the 
regulatory regime to allow for local governments to become more self-financing, the TA will 
foster the strategy’s first pillar of broad-based economic growth. By helping streamline public 
services and making them more accessible, the TA contributes to its second pillar, inclusive 
development. The TA’s support for social audits and regulatory impact analysis strengthens 
public management and contributes to the strategy’s third pillar of good governance.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
5.  Bhutan has achieved robust economic growth in the past decade. Its gross domestic 
product has grown an average of 7% per annum since 2004. Its per capita gross national 
income rose almost threefold from $730 in 2000 to $1,900 in 2008. With additional hydropower 
projects in the pipeline that promise additional revenues, Bhutan’s economic outlook remains 
bright. To ensure that the country’s growth is balanced and sustainable, the government is 
pursuing a development agenda anchored on both democratization and decentralization.  
 
6.  Since the country’s transition to parliamentary democracy in 2008, the government has 
adopted additional mechanisms to institutionalize decentralized public management. Notable

governments. The government is also developing a framework for assigning responsibilities to 
local bodies to promote appropriate usage of block grants and to foster greater accountability.  
 
7.  As it embarks on an agenda of development through decentralization, the government 
recognizes its enormous challenges. Chief among these are weak institutional and human 
resource  capacity  at  local  levels,  the  inadequate  resource  base  of  local  economies  and 
institutions, cumbersome and bureaucratic administrative systems, and procedures that have 
hampered the efficiency and effectiveness of local administration (footnote 3, p.70). At the same 
time, Bhutan’s country competitiveness needs major improvement. Its ranking in the worldwide 
Doing Business survey remains in the bottom quarter (ranking 142 in the 2011 report).9 In South 
Asia, Bhutan only ranked better than Afghanistan in the 2010 survey.  
   
8.  To  meet  these  challenges,  the government  is  pursuing  various  strategies  under  its 
current 5-year plan. While the strategies are well-defined, major gaps exist in terms of financing, 
technology, accountability, regulation, and capacity. The TA will work to fill these gaps through 
activities to advance policy reforms in local government finance, apply information technology to 
enhance public services, improve bureaucratic performance through social audit mechanisms, 
and foster institutional efficiencies by streamlining policies and regulations. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact of the TA will be more effective public sector management at the national 
and local levels in Bhutan to improve social welfare and the business environment. This impact 
will be measured by (i) two indicators in Bhutan’s global ranking in the Doing Business survey—
―starting a business‖ and ―paying taxes‖; and (ii) the expected increase in the percentage of 
citizens expressing satisfaction with the delivery of government services. 
   
10.   The outcome of the TA will be enhanced capacity of the national and local governments 
to deliver sustainable public services that are responsive to the needs and preferences of 
citizens and businesses. This outcome will be measured by an increased share of municipal 
taxes in national revenue collection, an increase in the number of streamlined government 
services  accessible  online,  and  the  number  of  amended  or  abrogated  central  government 
regulations affecting local bodies as a result of regulatory impact analysis. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  To achieve the above impact and outcome, the four TA components will work to (i) 
advance local government finance reforms, (ii) enhance government performance through e-
governance and citizens’ participation, (iii) strengthen civil service reforms through management 
training, and (iv) improve regulatory capacity and reduce the government’s regulatory burden.  
 
12.  Component 1: Advancing local government finance reforms. The share of municipal 
taxes in Bhutan’s national revenues is a minuscule 0.07%.10 The government realizes that 
effective fiscal decentralization will require local governments to build their capacity to self-
                                                
9  International  Finance  Corporation.  Doing  Business.  Washington,  DC:  International  Finance  Corporation. 
http://www.doingbusiness.org. 
10 Royal Government of Bhutan, Ministry of Finance, Department of Revenue and Customs. 2010. National Revenue 
Report 2008–2009. Bhutan.

3 
 
finance their activities. With support from the Ministry of Finance (MOF), the Department of 
Urban Development and Engineering Services (DUDES) of the Ministry of Works and Human 
Settlements  has  proposed  a  municipal  finance  policy  to  the  cabinet.  The  DUDES  is 
spearheading  this  policy  because  the  reforms  are  targeted  at  the  country’s  four  Class  A 
thromdes (municipalities), which are subject to DUDES’ regulatory jurisdiction.11 The proposed 
policy, now under review, seeks to enhance the revenues of these municipalities by rationalizing 
the local revenue structure (taxes, fees, and charges) and maximizing the use of public assets. 
The  TA  will  help  operationalize  this  policy,  applying  best  practices  in  land  valuation,  and 
updating property tax rates. In consultation with the National Land Commission (NLC), the TA 
will also assist DUDES in reviewing the land registration process in municipalities to ensure it 
becomes more efficient and well linked to automation efforts of the NLC and the G2C project. 
 
13.  The TA will assist the MOF in reviewing the requirements of local government finance for 
the dzongkhags (districts) and the gewogs (village groups) and in formulating options for a more 
coherent policy framework. Following the expected implementation of the municipal finance 
policy,12 the TA will also help the MOF formulate options for an updated regulatory framework 
for  local  government  finance.  The  MOF  recognizes  that  the  strength  and  sustainability  of 
decentralization depends greatly on the ability of local bodies to generate their own revenues.  
 
14.  Component  2:  Enhancing  government  performance  using  e-governance  and 
citizens’  participation.  International  experience  has  shown  that  information  and 
communications technology tools can introduce significant efficiencies, increase access, and 
lower costs in the delivery of public services. It has also demonstrated that public service 
delivery can be enhanced through citizens’ feedback mechanisms similar to those of customer 
relationship management innovations in the private sector. In this respect, the TA will work with 
the  Department  of  Local  Governance  of  the  Ministry  of  Home  and  Cultural  Affairs—in 
cooperation with the local development division of the Gross National Happiness Commission—
to implement innovations in e-governance and citizens’ participation.  
 
15.  E-governance is a government priority because it promises high accessibility to, and 
better responsiveness of, public services at comparatively low costs. The TA will help evaluate 
and monitor the design and operations of the e-governance portal of the government-to-citizen 
(G2C) project, which will provide citizens with web access to a wide range of public services. 
The  G2C  project  has  identified  the  top  75  commonly  used  government  services  to  be 
streamlined and offered through the portal.13 The G2C project will procure the needed hardware 
and software and ADB will provide technical expertise for quality control in procurement, design, 
and delivery. This activity will be linked to a separate ADB TA to be proposed in 2011 for a tax 
administration management information system (TAMIS) for the Department of Revenue and 
Customs (DRC). The e-filing and other services in the TAMIS will be included in the G2C portal 
and the TA will help procure equipment for the system.  
 
16.  Citizens’ participation is also a government priority because it is seen as essential to 
transparency and accountability. In this regard, the TA will support the conduct of citizens’ 
feedback surveys for participatory policy development, implementation, and monitoring. It will 
help the government design survey instruments, train interviewers, and analyze survey data. 
Baseline surveys will be conducted during the TA inception. The focus will be the services 
                                                
11 These thromdes are Gelephu, Phuentsholing, Samdrup Jongkhar, and Thimphu. 
12 See footnote 4. At present, the revenues of the dzongkhags and gewogs come mainly from an intergovernmental 
transfer system that started in 2000–2001.  
13 These 75 services are drawn from the work of five ministries and one autonomous agency. For a list of these

4 
 
provided by the G2C project. To measure performance relative to baseline figures, the TA will 
provide support for the conduct of additional surveys at the midpoint and in the last quarter of 
the project. The findings of these activities will be reported through mass media to foster greater 
public knowledge, bureaucratic accountability, and performance competition among agencies. 
 
17.  Component  3:  Strengthening  civil  service  through  management  development 
training.  Proper  implementation  of government  policies  and  programs  depends greatly  on 
personnel capacity. The TA will continue management development training for central and 
local officials organized by the Royal Institute of Management (RIM) under ADB’s ongoing TA 
(footnote 6). The TA will support faculty development and the design of modules as well as a 
secondment program that will place national officials in dzongkhags and have officials from 
dzongkhags  work  at  central  offices.  This  secondment  program  is  being  piloted  under  the 
ongoing TA. The TA will review the pilot program and the results will inform the design of the 
follow-on  program.  The  MOF  asked  that  the  secondment  include  officials  from  various 
ministries. RIM faculty members could be considered for secondment as well. Through this 
secondment program, the TA will deepen the officials’ capability for implementing policies and 
programs. 
 
18.  Component 4: Improving regulatory capacity and reducing regulatory burdens on 
government agencies. The government is cognizant of its policy gaps and inconsistencies and 
of regulatory burdens on ministries and agencies delivering public services. As a result of ADB’s 
TA on small and medium-sized enterprises, the government has mandated that policy makers 
be schooled in regulatory impact analysis (RIA).14 The TA will support capacity building for basic 
and advanced RIA courses for policy and planning development officers and legal officers of 
ministries as well as incoming civil servants. Support for external training for the RIA task force 
may also be provided. RIA training will be delivered by RIM, select officials, and consultants.  
 
19.  In  terms  of  impact,  the  TA  assumes  that  government  support  for  improving 
administrative  performance  will  be  sustained.  The  risk  is  that  changes  in  leadership  in 
government agencies could reduce support for the TA. In terms of outcome, the TA assumes 
that central and local governments will be able to work together in advancing reforms. The risk 
is that government priorities could shift due to unexpected fiscal pressures and insufficient 
resources to sustain service innovations. The TA will mitigate these risks by broadening TA 
ownership across key agencies and by partnering with the externally funded G2C project. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
20.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at the equivalent of $890,000. The TA will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). ADB will 
provide the equivalent of $850,000 and the government will finance the balance, equivalent to 
$40,000. The financing will cover the cost of a consulting firm that will implement the TA as well 
as  procurement  of  equipment.  The  government  contribution  will  be  in  the  form  of  staff 
remuneration, office space for consultants, and facilities for trainings. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
21.  The executing agency will be the MOF. The MOF will appoint a project director to chair 
the project steering committee. The project will have four implementing agencies, each of which 
                                                
14  ADB. 2007. Proposed Asian Development Fund Grants on Micro, Small, and Medium-Sized Enterprise Sector 
Development Program. Manila (Grant 0089-BHU).

5 
 
will be represented in the steering committee together with ADB. These will be the MOF for 
component 1 (including procurement of equipment), the Department of Local Governance for 
component 2, the Royal Civil Service Commission for component 3, and RIM for component 4. 
The TA is expected to start in January 2011 and end in December 2013. 
 
22.  A consulting firm will be contracted to implement the TA. The firm will field a project 
management specialist (national, 12 person-months) who will serve as project manager. For 
component 1, the firm will field a local government finance specialist (international, 6 person-
months) to work with the MOF and the DUDES in operationalizing aspects of the proposed 
municipal finance policy. The specialist will conduct institutional, policy, and regulatory reviews 
of the local government finance sector and draft options for enhancing local government finance.  
 
23.  For component 2, the firm will field an e-governance specialist (international, 4 person-
months) and a system engineering and network specialist (international, 6 person-months) who 
will work with the G2C project in evaluating and monitoring the implementation of G2C initiatives. 
Both specialists will also work in setting up a web portal to give citizens easy access and better 
transparency  in  tax  transactions.  A  public  sector  management  specialist  (international,  2 
person-months) will assist the G2C project in the automation of land registration and in the 
general change management needs of the TA. In addition, the firm will field a survey research 
specialist  (international,  2  person-months)  who  will  design  survey  questionnaires,  train 
interviewers, supervise the surveys, and present findings. For component 3, the firm will support 
RIM and consultants as needed for the training. It will assist the Royal Civil Service Commission 
in the design of its secondment program. For component 4, the firm will field a regulatory reform 
specialist (international, 2 person-months) who will lead the design and delivery of RIA training. 
The specialist will conduct a regulatory analysis of policies governing local administration and 
prepare a paper on regulatory reforms to enhance local government performance.  
 
24.  The consulting firm will be engaged using ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). The selection will be quality- and cost-based selection 
using the 80:20 quality–cost ratio and will call for simplified technical proposals. Procurement of 
equipment will be carried out by the MOF in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines 
(2010, as amended from time to time). At the end of the TA, the equipment will be turned over to 
the  MOF,  which  has  demonstrated  capacity  to  operate  information  technology  systems.15 
Disbursement under the TA will be made in accordance with the ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
25.  Workshops  and  booklets  on  best  practices  and  lessons  learned  in  the  TA  will  be 
published in Bhutan. These workshops and publications will be organized with technical inputs 
from ADB staff. Technical assistance reports will be made publicly available on the ADB website. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
26.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $850,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Bhutan for Strengthening Public Management, and hereby reports this action 
to the Board. 
                                                
15  Under the MOF, the DRC established the Bhutan automated customs system in 2001, the revenue management 
system in 2002, and the sales tax system in 2009. The DRC has 91 staff in its administrative and IT division.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Strengthening  Public  Management  in  Bhutan  will  be 
implemented by a consulting firm that will be competitively procured in accordance with the guidelines of 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The firm will field a team of international and national consultants. 
The firm will also deploy a project manager who will manage the day-to-day operations of the TA. The 
implementation of the TA will be supervised by a project director appointed by the government. The 
following  positions  and  their  respective  terms  of  references  are  envisioned  as  needed  for  the 
implementation of the TA. All consultants will be engaged from July 2011 to June 2013. 
2.   Local government finance specialist (international, 6 person-months). The local government 
finance (LGF) specialist will have at least 10 years of work experience in public finance, with at least 5 
years working on municipal finance issues. He or she will have at least a master’s degree in finance, 
economics, public policy, or a similarly relevant discipline. The specialist will preferably have worked 
previously in Bhutan or in other South Asian countries on related international development assignments. 
The  LGF  specialist  should  have  demonstrated  experience  in  successfully  managing  teams  in 
development  projects.  The  principal  objective  of  this  position  is  to  manage  the  implementation  of 
component 1 of the TA (advancing local government finance reforms). The LGF specialist will provide 
policy and programmatic support to the Ministry of Finance and the Ministry of Works and Human 
Settlements on local government finance policy reforms. The LGF specialist will  
 
 (i)   assess the issues constraining local government finances in Bhutan within an agreed 
service delivery commitment at the local level; 
(ii)   prepare an expenditure plan on a normative basis for major municipalities; 
(iii)   prepare a medium-term fiscal framework for major municipalities with alternative fiscal 
deficit scenarios; 
(iv)   prepare a detailed revenue mobilization plan for the major municipalities to include their 
own sources of revenue and tariff setting for provision of services; 
(v)   prepare a road map that includes institutional arrangements for revenue sharing between 
the central government and the municipalities; 
(vi)   prepare a tax administration modernization plan for major municipalities; 
(vii)   assess the scope for private investment in service delivery; and 
(viii)   organize a public awareness program and assist in implementing the proposed municipal 
finances reform. 
 
3.  Deliverables and reports. The LGF specialist will submit a work plan 1 week after engagement 
and will prepare (i) the publication of policy papers on local government finance sector reforms, with 
recommendations on institutional, policy, and regulatory reforms, and (ii) a   report  on  the 
implementation of the municipal finance policy. The reports will be submitted for review and approval by 
ADB and the government.  
 
4.   E-governance specialist (international, 4 person-months). The e-governance specialist will 
have a university degree in information technology, business administration, engineering, economics or 
related fields, preferably at post-graduate level or the equivalent. He or she must have at least 8 years of 
relevant professional work experience in the information and communications technology (ICT) and 
development field, including work related to ICT for development and the bridging of the digital divide and 
providing ICT access in the rural areas. The specialist will preferably have worked previously in South 
Asia on international development assignments and must have demonstrated experience in successfully 
managing teams in development projects. The e-governance specialist will help implement component 2 
of  the  TA  (enhancing  government  performance  using  e-governance  and  citizens’  participation). 
Specifically, he or she will provide support for the implementation, coordination, and monitoring of the 
government-to-citizen  (G2C)  project’s  e-governance  initiatives.  He  or  she  will  also  assist  in  the 
implementation of tax administration management information system (TAMIS) of the Department of 
Revenue and Customs (DRC), which will be linked to the G2C project. The e-governance specialist will

(xiv)  assist in training and provide professional advice on functional requirements, problem

7.  Deliverables and reports. The consultant will submit a work plan 1 week after engagement and 
will prepare various reports as requested by ADB, including functional requirements and IT infrastructure 
requirements for the TAMIS.  
 
8.  Survey research specialist (international, 2 person-months). The survey research specialist 
should have at least 10 years’ work experience in designing and managing surveys and market research 
activities and, preferably, will have worked at least 5 years on public sector surveys and research-related 
assignments. He or she will have at least a master’s degree in economics, political science, public policy, 
public  administration,  or  a  similarly  relevant  discipline.  Specialized  training  in  survey  research 
methodologies will be highly desired. The specialist will preferably have worked previously in Bhutan or in 
other South Asian countries on related international development assignments. The main objective of this 
position is to lead the implementation of component 2 of the TA (enhancing government performance 
using supply and demand side mechanisms). The survey research specialist will be responsible for the 
development and delivery of survey research tools that will be used by the government and other 
stakeholders. He or she will develop pilot survey questionnaires, train survey interviewers, supervise the 
conduct of surveys in the pilot areas, and analyze and present survey results. The survey research will 
 
(i)  review survey research products in Bhutan and design survey questionnaires and a 
sampling strategy; 
(ii)  solicit and integrate feedback on survey questionnaires from government counterparts; 
(iii)  conduct a pre-test of survey questionnaires in select local governments; 
(iv)  analyze results of the pre-test and finalize survey questionnaires for citizens’ feedback 
surveys; 
(v)  train survey interviewers; 
(vi)  supervise the conduct of the baseline survey, midterm survey, and end-of-project survey;  
(vii)  draft analysis of surveys and help develop citizens’ report cards based on the surveys; 
(viii)  present findings in various workshops and forums; and 
(ix)  do other related tasks, as required by ADB and the government. 
 
9.  Deliverables and reports. The survey research specialist will submit a work plan 1 week after his 
or her engagement. He or she will submit the design of survey research questionnaires for the approval of 
ADB and the government. The specialist will draft and submit three reports on the baseline survey results, 
the midterm survey results, and end-of-project survey results.  
 
10.   Development  management  training  specialist  (international,  2  person-months).  The 
development management training (DMT) specialist will have at least 10 years of experience working in 
international development, including at least 5 years working on local governance and service delivery 
issues. He or she will have at least a master’s degree in economics, political science, public policy, public 
administration,  or  a  similarly  relevant  discipline.  The  DMT  specialist  will  preferably  have  worked 
previously in Bhutan or in other South Asian countries on related international development assignments. 
The  principal  objective  of  this  position  is  to  lead  the  implementation  of  component  3  of  the  TA 
(strengthening civil service through management development training). The DMT specialist will be 
responsible for the design and delivery of management development training programs. He or she will 
work closely with the Royal Institute of Management (RIM) and the Royal Civil Service Commission. The 
DMT specialist will conduct a training needs assessment and review the government’s secondment 
program. He or she will contribute to the selection of participants in the training and secondment as well 
as lead the delivery of training by serving as a faculty member and resource person. The DMT specialist 
will 
 
(i)  review integrated capacity development plans of local governments; 
(ii)  conduct training needs assessment of selected local governments;

(iii)  design basic and advanced level development management training programs; 
(iv)  develop training manuals for basic and advanced level courses; 
(v)  develop criteria for officials to be nominated for training programs; 
(vi)  conduct pilot basic and advanced level training programs; 
(vii)  review the feedback of officials and revise the design of training programs; 
(viii)  design and implement an expanded training program for officials of local governments;  
(ix)  other related tasks, as required by ADB and the government. 
 
11.  Deliverables  and  reports:  The  DMT  specialist  will  be  responsible  for  the  delivery  of  10 
development management courses for local governments based on their integrated capacity building 
plans.  The LG specialist is expected to submit the following documents for review and approval by ADB 
and the government: (i) course outlines, (ii) course syllabi, and (iii) training evaluations. 
 
12.  Regulatory  reform  specialist  (international,  2  person  months).  The  regulatory  reform 
specialist will have at least 10 years of work experience in international development, with at least 5 
years’ work experience in regulatory reforms in developed and/or developing countries. He or she will 
have at least a master’s degree in economics, political science, public policy, public administration, or a 
similarly relevant discipline. The regulatory reform specialist will preferably have worked previously in 
Bhutan  or  in  other  South  Asian  countries  on  related  international  development  assignments.  The 
specialist will be responsible for the implementation of component 4 of the TA (improving regulatory 
capacity and reducing regulatory burdens on government agencies). He or she will work closely with RIM 
and the Ministry of Economic Affairs in the design and delivery of the capacity-building programs. The 
regulatory reform specialist will 
 
(i)  work with RIM to develop the regulatory impact analysis (RIA) training of trainers plan 
and curriculum;  
(ii)  help selected government officials serve as adjunct faculty in RIA training;  
(iii)  conduct RIA training of trainers;  
(iv)  deliver various RIA training modules;  
(v)  conduct a study on the regulatory burden of local governments in Bhutan;  
(vi)  organize workshops to formulate a response to the results of the regulatory reform study; 
(vii)  draft a strategy paper on regulatory reform of local governments;  
(viii)  provide  advisory  services  to  streamline  policies  and  regulations  to  enhance  local 
governance; and 
(ix)  do other related tasks, as required by ADB and the government. 
 
13.  Deliverables and reports. The regulatory reform specialist will submit a work plan 1 week after 
initiating assignment. He or she will deliver at least two basic and advanced level training courses for 
officials on RIA. He or she will also submit a report on a regulatory analysis and recommendations to 
streamline central government policies and regulation, including those focused on local governance. The 
specialist will also prepare other reports as requested by ADB and the government and submit these 
reports to both parties for review and approval.

with at least 5 years’ work experience in change management or related programs. He or she will have at 
least  a master’s degree in  public management, business administration, psychology, or  a similarly 
relevant discipline. Preferably, he or she would have relevant work experience in the information and 
communications technology (ICT) and development field, including work related to ICT for development.
